image.altText: Krystal and Anastasia Marshall hug and smile.

props.synopsis: Anastasia Marshall, who was charged with murder after her ex-wife Krystal Marshall was found dead at the scene of a house fire in Adelaide's south, is granted home detention bail, but police prosecutors ask the Supreme Court to review the decision.

title.children: Ex-wife accused of murdering Krystal Marshall granted home detention bail

image.altText: Malinauskas refugees

props.synopsis: New arrivals in SA from war-torn countries will receive additional support from the state government as part of a new humanitarian package.

title.children: SA unveils additional support for new arrivals fleeing conflict

image.altText: Perth Police drug testing kit

props.synopsis: Roadside instant drug testing is under scrutiny after an Adelaide driver falsely tested positive to methamphetamine, but experts say the benefits of their use may outweigh the risks.

title.children: A false positive on a roadside drug test saw a man lose his licence. How widely are they used in Australia?

image.altText: A blue and brown sign reading "Mount Gambier Courthouse" with a brick building in the back

props.synopsis: An Kingston SE man in his 80s will likely die in prison after he was sentenced for sexually abusing children across 30 years.

title.children: Elderly SA man sentenced to 25 years' jail for child sexual abuse spanning decades

image.altText: A girl wearing a black T-shirt and shorts holding a netball near a netball ring and clubhouse

props.synopsis: The regional SA netball league the teenager plays for has become one of the first to adopt a policy allowing players to wear shorts instead of dresses or skirts, hoping it will help recruit more players.

title.children: Ashleigh would rather skip her netball games than wear a dress. Now, she can play in shorts

image.altText: housing estate shot from a drone

props.synopsis: The South Australian Greens propose reforms requiring vendors pay for and provide current building inspections on properties for sale, potentially saving buyers thousands of dollars.

title.children: SA Greens seek reforms requiring property sellers provide pre-purchase building inspections

image.altText: Minister for Foreign Affairs Penny Wong speaks to journalists in canberra on monday october 16, 2023

props.synopsis: Australia will resume funding to the United Nations aid agency for Palestinians, UNRWA, Foreign Minister Penny Wong has announced.

title.children: Australia to resume funding to UN Palestinian aid agency UNRWA

image.altText: A woman sitting at a park

props.synopsis: Laura Murphy says women deserve more information about the potential risks involved in a common surgical procedure.

title.children: Laura wasn't told her operation could cause infertility. She says doctors are leaving women in the dark

image.altText: AGED CARE workers.

props.synopsis: Aged care workers win their years-long Fair Work case for a wage rise of between 7 and 28.5 per cent for the entire sector.

title.children: Aged care workers win up to 28.5 per cent wage rise after years-long fight

image.altText: Peter Dutton sits in the House of Representatives

props.synopsis: The CSIRO has rebuked politicians seeking to undermine its research showing nuclear energy would be much more expensive than solar or wind power, after Liberal leader Peter Dutton claimed that research had been "discredited".

title.children: CSIRO boss hits back at Dutton over nuclear power research

image.altText: Toyota Hilux

props.synopsis: The Coalition says Labor's proposed fuel efficiency standards constitute a tax on utes and family cars. What do the experts say?

title.children: We fact checked Peter Dutton on whether Labor's new fuel efficiency standards are a 'ute tax'. Here's what we found

image.altText: A generic photo of ASX board.

props.synopsis: The Australian share market has ended lower on Friday, but recovered slightly after falling sharply as investors worried hotter-than-expected inflation in the US could delay global interest rate cuts. Look back on the day's financial news as it happened with our blog.

title.children: ASX ends lower despite late recovery from US interest rate worries, Optus services 'progressively restored' after customer call issues — as it happened

image.altText: Two men wearing industrial ear muffs, black protective glasses and caps in a small room with electrical equipment.

props.synopsis: Bitcoin mining was about to end both Andy and Russ's marriages until they met each other and set up a "farm". But now they face more hurdles, as a pre-coded dystopian event looms and crypto-cynics predict a crash.

title.children: Russ and Andy had 'Frankenstein's monster' in their living rooms, so they joined forces to set up a Bitcoin farm

image.altText: A graphic showing a positive COVID-19 RAT, a representation of the virus and a woman blowing her nose.

props.synopsis: The state's chief health officer says the description wrongly implied long-term post-COVID viral symptoms were "somehow unique and exceptional" to other viral infections.

title.children: Queensland's Chief Health Officer says it's time to stop using the term 'long COVID'

image.altText: Head shot of a person with a beard and long brunette hair who appears warm and smiling.

props.synopsis: The popular feel-good Netflix show Queer Eye has been rocked by accusations of a toxic workplace behind the scenes, with the most popular cast member facing the worst of the allegations. Why does the story of the kind celebrity falling from grace sound so familiar?

title.children: 'How do I process this information?': What happens when a beloved celebrity falls from grace

image.altText: A composite of Meghan, Duchess of Sussex and the words American Riviera Orchard.

props.synopsis: The Duchess of Sussex launches her new brand, hinting at a potential pivot to lifestyle content, in her first post in nearly four years. Here's what we know so far.

title.children: Meghan Markle returns to social media with new brand amid Princess Kate speculation

image.altText: The word Cranbrook in gold on a sandstone column at the gates of a school.

props.synopsis: As both the federal government and Cranbrook announce investigations into the prestigious boys' school, Four Corners has been inundated with new concerning allegations.

title.children: Four Corners still had more questions for Cranbrook. They were met with more legal threats

image.altText: A rice field in Bali

props.synopsis: Two foreign tourists including an Australian woman have been killed on the Indonesian resort island of Bali after heavy rain triggered a landslide that swept away their villa, an official said on Thursday.

title.children: Australian woman killed in Bali landslide

image.altText: Andrew Giles during QT

props.synopsis: Muslim community organisations are unhappy after grants announced for Muslim and Jewish communities to improve social cohesion were given to two news organisations and the Human Rights Commission instead of Islamic and Arab groups.

title.children: Muslim and Arab leaders incensed over distribution of social cohesion grants five months into war

image.altText: Carlos Alcaraz hides his face from a swarm of bees at Indian Wells Masters 1000.

props.synopsis: A mass of bees on centre court causes a lengthy delay in the men's quarterfinal between Carlos Alcaraz and Alexander Zverev at Indian Wells.

title.children: 'Bee invasion' suspends play for almost two hours in Alcaraz-Zverev quarterfinal at Indian Wells

image.altText: Spectators gather to watch the spacecraft launch in Texas. They all point at the sky

props.synopsis: SpaceX's Starship rocket, designed to eventually send astronauts to the Moon, completed nearly an entire test flight after two previous failures.

title.children: SpaceX Starship disintegrates after completing most of test flight

image.altText: Man standing in a room with rubble everywhere cupping his hands with pasta inside

props.synopsis: The Palestinian Authority appoints Mohammad Mustafa as the new prime minister at a tumultuous time, while US Senate Majority Leader Chuck Schumer harshly criticises Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and calls for new elections.

title.children: IDF describes Palestinian reports of Israeli strikes killing at least 29 Gazans awaiting aid as 'false'

image.altText: An Imam wearing traditional dress looks at the camera with the red rocky ranges of Alice Springs behind him.

props.synopsis: It should be Islam's "month of happiness" but as the Israel-Gaza war continues, Imam Ahmad Aboukhadra doesn't feel the joy of Ramadan he once did.

title.children: This Ramadan, the pain of Palestinians is weighing heavily on Australian Muslims

image.altText: A man in a blue suit holds an envelope in his left hand.

props.synopsis: It's time to test your knowledge about the news of the week.

title.children: Weekly news quiz: From Oscars to who 'killed' Princess Catherine's photo, were you paying attention this week?

image.altText: NSW shadow attorney-general Alister Henskens in speaks in state parliament.

props.synopsis: Senior planning department official Katie Joyner is accused of allegedly purchasing a property in the upper north shore suburb of Gordon within one of the government's planned Transport Oriented Development zones, before the policy was made public.

title.children: Planning bureaucrat at centre of corruption scandal named under parliamentary privilege

image.altText: Scott Morrison in a grandstand swinging a Sharks jersey around his head, holding a beer.

props.synopsis: The former PM is a longtime public supporter of the Sharks, concluding his final speech in parliament last month with the team's motto: "And, as always — up, up Cronulla."

title.children: Scott Morrison to hand back 'number 1 ticketholder' title at Cronulla Sharks

image.altText: Hitchhiking in Canada

props.synopsis: Alice Garner hitchhiked long distances with her dad when she was young, but she says she wouldn't let her daughter do it today. Why did it become viewed as a dangerous pursuit rather than an adventurous one?

title.children: Hitchhikers were once a common sight on the side of Australian roads. So what's changed?

image.altText: A yarn sculpture of a grass tree is silhouetted by a golden sunset by the beach.

props.synopsis: Art observers at Perth's Cottesloe Beach for this year's Sculpture by the Sea exhibition are rolling up their sleeves to help create Noongar artist Sharon Egan's display.

title.children: This artwork grows the longer it's on display, and it's making history at Sculpture by the Sea

image.altText: Caroline Page stands in the kitchen her two sons sitting at a bench

props.synopsis: Australia's child support system is outdated and not keeping pace with inflation, according to critics, who say it disproportionately disadvantages women.

title.children: 'Child support is an archaic system': Debts continue to rise as critics call for overhaul

image.altText: Two teenage girls wearing green and gold soccer jurnseys look at the camera, while one holds a soccer ball.

props.synopsis: Football NSW is making a case for more funding after a 34 per cent jump in player registrations in what is being dubbed the 'Matildas effect.'

title.children: 'Matildas effect' sees 34pc increase in soccer players in NSW, with women and girls fastest growing group

image.altText: Hani sitting listening to headphoens on the plane.

props.synopsis: Finally escaping the horrors of the Gaza Strip and holding onto hope for some reprieve, Hani has found himself trapped in visa limbo.

title.children: Hani thought he'd escaped the horrors of Gaza. Then his Australian visa was suddenly cancelled

image.altText: Lana Del Rey, Taylor Swift and Jack Antonoff at the 66th Grammy Awards, 4 Feb 2024 in Los Angeles

props.synopsis: Super producer Jack Antonoff explains how Taylor Swift gave him his big break, and gives us an insight into what inspires his process.

title.children: How Jack Antonoff became the man Taylor Swift, Lorde and Lana Del Rey trusted with their music

image.altText: This image released by Universal Pictures shows Cillian Murphy in a scene from Oppenheimer.

props.synopsis: Japanese viewers appear split ahead of the delayed domestic release of Christopher Nolan's biopic of the father of the atomic bomb.

title.children: Why the global blockbuster Oppenheimer has been screened everywhere except Japan

image.altText: Two images next to each other of a turtle head close-up with a white iris looking right, and an echidna close-up looking left

props.synopsis: Echidnas are known for laying eggs and eating ants, but it turns out a few have developed a hunger for the eggs of endangered turtles.

title.children: Echidnas caught sucking the life out of threatened turtle eggs for the first time

image.altText: man standing in front of tractor holding barley

props.synopsis: How Australian growers are making some of your favourite beer brands taste consistently good.

title.children: From paddock to pint, Australian brewers are getting fussy about beer barley
